intro: Abutilon mauritianum subsp. mauritianum, commonly known as the Mauritius velvetleaf, is a flowering plant native to Madagascar. It is characterized by its heart-shaped leaves and showy, lantern-shaped yellow flowers that bloom in clusters. The plant is typically shrub-like, with smooth, often hairy stems that can grow up to several meters in height. It thrives in tropical and subtropical climates, preferring well-drained soil and full sun exposure. Its ornamental value makes it a popular choice for gardens, though it can become invasive in certain regions.

The plant is often seen in disturbed areas and is adaptable to various soil types. Its native range spans much of sub-Saharan Africa, with some occurrences in the Arabian Peninsula.

It was originally from Madagascar and was brought to Hawaii as an ornamental plant due to its attractive foliage and flowers. The plant thrives in tropical and subtropical climates, leading to its rapid spread across native ecosystems.
